item.title: NEW PITCH TO THE WORLD REGARDING GLOBAL LIFE SATISFACTION
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: Madam Christine Lagarde had already committed $0.5 bn to my project, but I will begin to make another pitch. There is a lot of talk about who will own the future of technology these days on The Economist. Apparently it is all about AI and quantum computing and so on. You see, I don't see the world from this sort of tech giants and big money and large political decisions and so on. My view of the world is individual focused. It does not matter that you use AI or speed up CPU speed, and so on. What matters to me is that individuals living a short life on Earth have tools to have the best meaningful and fulfilling life that can be afforded to them. Technology is secondary in my conception of the world. I mean during Roman Empire times, how much writing was about how aqueducts will change the lives of people and how chariots will make the old forms of travel obsolete and a huge amount of rara? It's just a strange age where irrelevant small issues get a huge amount of visibility. We remember Suetenius in The Twelve Caesars. Neither then, nor today, is it any less grand and amazing that we are living breathing human beings and we have the opportunity to live meaningful lives. I am interested in that aspect of human existence, and so tools we use to address improvements here, technology, is not the center of attention. They exist to enhance human lives. I totally detest techno-porn mumbo jumbo.

item.title: LOOK BILL GATES I WILL HIRE PEOPLE WHO WANT TO WORK WITH ME OK?

I don't obsess about control, and find the idea of cutting into anyone's eyes, blood meta, and deep interior just totally vile, evil, disgusting, and low. You revel in it. I don't want to hire people who do not want to work with me and accept the things I am working on as important. I don't give a damn if they are white, Asian, black, Hispanic or whatever. I know how to treat people with respect and I know what people need to feel well-treated by their colleagues and their place of work. You never did. You spent more time tracking who was in the office at early Microsoft by memorising license plates than you did worrying about their working conditions. You screwed over Paul Allen who was a better coder than you because you were a greedy mother fucker. Don't tell me how to deal with people low evil son of a bitch.

item.title: WHY "DO WHAT YOU'RE TOLD" IS FRIVOLOUS AND VALUELESS IN THE RIGHT SORT OF WORLD
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Let's start with an easy example. Suppose you're a surgeon, a heart surgeon, for 20 years. You have an emergency case and a man arrives at the emergency room and needs operation to live. You don't need to be told anything. You rush off put on your various funky clothes and you're in the operating room with your colleagues. What is 'do what you're told' here? It's just rubbish here. People doing things that they have trained for 8 years and then worked on for 20 years do not have any 'do what you're told' because gaining proficiency gives them the habit of doing some things.

Well this is the way everything is in the end. In work life of any person, 'do what you're told' does not even belong in the professional life. People end up doing things from long practice of doing the same thing and have relative autonomy in doing it based on industrial regulations and best practices and there are many things that end up making 'do what you're told' become inappropriate frivolous drama. We see those things sometime, but that's because professionalisation and division of labour is imperfect. People who are passionate and serious about nontrivial work do not actually benefit from being in the bad environments where some idiot with some high position pretends he's a prison warden and slave driver. Those things do not belong in civilised society.

item.title: HOW MUCH EMOTIONS MATTER
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Mr. Bearden,
I have been in Finance from 1995 at Lehman, and that's a long time. I was not going up in any ladder directly but I am a very good quant.  So let me tell you what I think about the problem of assuming that personal emotions matter.  It's my own understanding.   You see, Bill Gates is the sort of Feudal Tyrannical Monarch who will get pissed off the moment you have not given him control of your body parts and sacrificed you firstborn to honour his divinity.  You cannot avoid pissing off people like that, so it does not matter.  

Now on to much more normal people like Madam Lagarde.  Whether she gets emotionally upset or not does not actually matter for you.  She is visible in Finance.  Your actual problem in not delivering what you advertise will be quite different from her retaliating because her ego got hurt.  She's far past all that.  Yes, I can tell.  Even I am not all that relatiatory because I got upset.  I'm 48 and know that if I am dealing with an institution, it's just an institution.  The real problem of not delivering what you advertise (investment banking services) in a visible case is that there will be a hundred analysts who are ambitious and use your response time and your various characteristics with five and six factors and take it down as a data point.  Then all around Finance Industry this data point will be collated by ambitious quants with all sorts of theories and convictions about how their genius theories will change the whole universe and put Morgan Stanley -- delivery time, failure rate, etc. etc. And put your action in 10,000 rows of data, write about their business risk models in prestigious and in-house journals, promote all sorts of charts and cool R graphics showing how cutting edge their analyses are and how they really deserved three Ph.D.s or maybe four because society has not compensated them for their genius and they are misunderstood, and boom, you're losing business because your action became a dot in their statistical models.  No one needs to get upset at all for your business to bleed.  

Thanks,
ZULFIKAR MOINUDDIN AHMED

item.title: NO QUANT WOULD CONSIDER MODELS THAT ARE NOT WIDE
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: I am a quant, so I can tell your right away, that I am never enthusiastic about even working on any models that are not universalisable. I don't give a damn if Morgan Stanley does something strange. I am not interested in gossip. I want to know what all investment banks are doing in the world. I want data from all investment banks. Even better I want an institutional model where data are available for all companies everywhere in the universe. That's what quants want, because it feels too menial for a quant to work on some itsy bitsy issue. Quants pride themselves in having figured out deep aspects of universal human behaviour. We love Behavioural Finance models that will give such tremendous insights that even a poor man from the Vietnamese port, reading our brilliant insights can easily construct a business plan to arbitrage the efficiencies of all companies, produce a new movement where there are all sorts of Cathedrals in France that got converted to large technological armies who are monitoring the business risks real-time across the world etc. We don't like small models.

item.title: ZULF ESTIMATES MADAM CHRISTINE LAGARDE'S BENEVOLENCE LEVEL
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
[latexpage]

Madam Christine Lagarde is a very good person, and she made the risk decision to allocate $500 mn with me for the Global Life Satisfaction project. I cannot actually get a precise metric for her goodness level, but it is worth trying to quantify it by any measurements. Here I will show you some bounds on her rarity. Obviously she is a complex human being and has many aspects unknown to me etc. but that's okay. Let's do this exercise. Our tool will be World Values Survey, and we will be interested in classifying her roughly. We choose trust of people of different religion (she is Jewish and I am originally Muslim but now honorary Christian and follow my own unique faith) and different nationality. She is French and I am Bengali-American, i.e. American but of Bengali background. So we can easily verify that we differ in religion and nationality. Good. I will then make the assumption that her benevolent decision implies a trust across these bounds. And then we will put her in the category of trust across both religion and nationality. The variables are Q62 (trust of people of a different religion) and Q63 (trust of people of a different nationality). The values are 1=trust completely, 2=trust somewhat, 3=do not trust very much, 4=do not trust at all.

\begin{tabular}{rrrrr}
\hline
& 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \
\hline
1 & 3.14 & 1.41 & 0.80 & 0.55 \
2 & 0.83 & 25.72 & 8.03 & 3.24 \
3 & 0.27 & 3.24 & 28.57 & 6.72 \
4 & 0.17 & 1.00 & 2.19 & 14.11 \
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{table}

Madam Lagarde falls in (1,1) in this case and that is 3.14% of the world's population. This is obviously not an exactly correct bounding, but has the virtue of being based on real measurements, and tells us that she is rarer in this sort of benevolence than 96% of the people of the world.

Now let's leave Madam Lagarde alone and examine this fascinating distribution over here. People who totally distrust people across religions and nationality boundaries are 14.11%. That is just fascinating, and then you have a bit more skew towards distrust 28.57% than mild trust 25.72. Note the beautiful diagonal concentration. Very few people trust completely people of other religions but distrust completely people of other nations (0.54%) and vice versa (0.17%). This actually gives us the estimate for global xenophobia, and that's 14.11% of the peoples of the world.

item.title: WHY DON'T I UPDATE MY VIEW OF ALL WHITE PEOPLE BASED ON HORRIFIC EXPERIENCE WITH BILL GATES
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
[latexpage] You know, there is a sort of rationality to determining your attitude towards the whole world by a sort of Bayesian update. The model is that you move along in your life, and you have your filtration of all knowledge, and then at every moment, you update and you get $\mathcal{F}_t \subset \mathcal{F}_{t+1}$ and so on. So every time you encounter a brown person who gives you a bad experience you say 'brown people more likely to be bad'. You can do that if you like, but I don't do that. Life is too short to take information just from individual encounters. So my view is holistic and not just based on experience of particular people. Bill Gates is a criminal fringe cat. I know that he is politically fringe lower than 0.01% of Americans, and he's a charlatan. He does not represent American white people in values. In essence he's like those neo-Nazi punk losers who are going around beating up black hobos in New York City every day. He does not actually belong in CIvilisation at all. I am not going to allow him to mess up my view of the human race as a whole. I am an immortal Genius and he is an amoeba. I am annoyed that US Government coddles cunts like Bill Gates instead of using lethal force to wipe them out.

If we each lived for 900-1000 years the Bayesian approach would be reasonable. We'd have 500 years of youthful experiences, all sorts of romance and James Bonding with the beautiful ladies of everywhere, then spend 200-300 years of maturity and productive life, and have figured out how people are by experience alone. Unfortunately our lives are too short for Bayesian learning.

item.title: MY POSITION ON SUPERIORITY FOR FAREED ZAKARIA
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
[latexpage]

The position I will explain here for the benefit of Fareed Zakaria is the following set of claims:
(a) It is idiotic to the highest order to claim that Indians are superior to whites or whites are superior to Indians. This will be almost uniformly meaningless. Therefore Bill Gates claim that whites are superior to non-whites is meaningless and idiotic.

(b) It is not idiotic in particular cases to claim that an individual is superior to another individual. I claim that I, as an individual, am superior to Bill Gates. I can provide many particular metrics where there exist metrics $Q_j(\cdot)$ such that $Q_j(Zulf) \ge Q_j(Bill)$ for say $1\le j \le 100$. I can then claim that these metrics will be sufficient to prove that I am superior to Bill Gates.

Let's start with academic achievements and education, say $Q_1$. Then I have a magna cum laude from Princeton University, took all the required courses, have no failing grades, have many graduate level mathematics courses, and he does not have a college degree at all. So that is just $Q_1$. I can produce more and more detailed characteristics, such as the quality of my actual accomplishments versus his; such as the quality of my Virtues compared to his, and so on.

Now Bill Gates says that whites are superior because he broke White Law, Christian Law, and US Law, to cut into my eyes, damage my blood meta very badly, mixing it with excrement and doing all manner of horrible things, and then into my deep interior, and has been trying to kill me for a year. Then he says "whites are superior because whites have power". Well let's leave all other whites out of this, because he's crazy and is fringe among whites.

Imagine Thomas Bernhard a great genius writer, is sitting in the park inspired by a new idea for a novel, and the park is peaceful. He's writing some notes, enjoying the wind. Imagine a man shows up from a van and comes out and says to him, "I am superior to you, because I have power to kill you." Thomas Bernhard is quite involved in his thought and writing, and he looks up. Says, "Hum, what? I am very sorry, please forgive me but I am rather busy. Could you go away?" The man is quite insistent. He says "I am superior to you. In fact my whole tribe is superior to your tribe." And he pulls out a gun and says, "I have the power to kill you. So I am superior." Then he shoots and kills Thomas Bernhard.

You see, Fareed Zakaria, there is no possibility of proving superiority in this way. Obviously Thomas Bernhard is superior to the other man. Yes, he had the power to kill, but he did not actually do anything other than a criminal murder. Power to kill is not criteria for superiority.

item.title: ZULF UNDERSTANDS WHY ROMANTIC MODERNS (MODERNISTS) ATTRACT ME SO MUCH
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: Disintegration of values was the theme of Hermann Broch and many other romantic moderns or modernists including T. S. Eliot. I am very interested in the problem, and have sought for unity in existence and am the first to exhibit Universal Human Moral Nature for the first time in history with empirical data. So here my achievements are quite monumental and point in the right direction for making sense of values, i.e. moral values, after chaos and confusion that lasted from 1880s to 2020s a century and a half. I am quite clear that I have the answer for my beloved people the Human Race on the question of values across the globe. And the answer is at the moment not very complex. Hermann Broch, Friedrich Nietzsche, Immanuel Kant, and many other thinkers have been confused about these issues for many many centuries. I am of course interested in getting my $500 mn actually with a bank account with Morgan Stanley to work on Global Life Satisfaction but I don't understand why Bill Gates is not already killed. I have real work to do. Do these US Government officials have no sense. I am a Great American Genius and they are allowing a murderous criminal to harm me instead of allowing me a decent life with money owed to me.

item.title: THE IDEA THAT THE RICHER MAN IS SUPERIOR TO THE POORER MAN IS ABSOLUTELY WRONG AND DISGUSTING
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: Note the 'disgusting' in the title. Now let me make an attempt to be objective. I don't think that money is bad. I am looking for funding from ECB of $500 mn right now. But I will not tolerate the suggestion that the richer man is superior to the poorer man. Let me bring in some context. First of all, I am poor at the moment, so let me not stand on ceremony and make clear that I am poor and I am superior to Bill Gates. I am poorer, and he is richer and I am superior to him. I will come back to this specific and interesting special case later. Now let me address the various ways in which it is not the case that the richer man is superior to the poorer man in slightly more distant example. Let's start with Robert Musil. Robert Musil wrote The Man Without Qualities towards the end of his life and died in poverty. There were many richer men at that time who were inferior to him in various ways. Buddha was poor and he was superior to most of the kings of the East. There are many criminals with a lot more money than pro bono doctors in America, and the pro bono doctors are superior to them. The idea that the richer man is superior to the poorer man is just total absurdity and actually disgusting. It is disgusting and not just wrong because of all the great men of the past who are being denigrated and were poor implicitly. For a Christian, this is obvious because Christ was not rich. So I strongly condemn anyone who dares suggest that the richer man is obviously superior to the poorer man. Wealth does not make anyone superior.

item.title: MINXIN PEI: I HAVE DISAGREEMENT HERE BUT WILL RETURN TO THIS
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Minxin Pei on why China will not surpass the United States

China will continue its rapid growth for a time, but it faces big obstacles—not least its ageing population and the stifling rule of the current regime

Aug 30th 2021

BY MINXIN PEI

This By-invitation commentary is part of a series by global thinkers on the future of American power—examining the forces shaping the country’s global standing. Read more here.

AMERICA’S CHAOTIC exit from Afghanistan must be seen by Chinese leaders as the latest proof of its irreversible decline. But their euphoria will be short-lived. As consummate realists, they know that President Joe Biden is taking the United States out of the “grave of empires” so that he can conserve America’s power to prevail against China in the next chapter of their contest for global supremacy.

In its essence, the United States-China “strategic competition” is less a confrontation between duelling ideologies than a familiar clash between a hegemonic power and its challenger. It seems reasonable to bet that although China will continue to narrow the gap in most dimensions of power in the coming two decades, it will ultimately fail to surpass America. This may elicit a sigh of relief in some quarters of Washington. But a China that has reached near-parity will nevertheless be a formidable geopolitical adversary.

America has adopted a strategy to thwart China’s rise. Framed as “economic decoupling”, this has featured a trade war to force global supply chains to relocate out of China and a tech war to choke off the flow of critical technologies and know-how to China. Few should doubt the efficacy of these measures—just witness how quickly American sanctions have crippled Huawei, the Chinese telecom giant that used to be the leader in 5G technology. But on its own this strategy will only slow down, not stop, China’s advance.

China still has relatively strong economic momentum in the coming decade. Its GDP is about 70% of America’s at market exchange rates (and is already larger than America’s at purchasing-power parity). Yet Chinese income per person, at slightly over $10,000 a year, is about one-sixth of Americans’ standard of living. This implies that China has a lot more room to grow, thanks to its huge internal market, its dynamic private sector and its vast pool of workers.

China will also make substantial, albeit slower, progress in the tech sector, despite American restrictions. Beijing has vowed to make huge investments in science and technology to reduce its vulnerability. To be sure, President Xi Jinping is unlikely to realise his ambition of full technological self-sufficiency. However, with millions of well-trained scientists and talented engineers, and trillions of dollars in R&D investment in the coming decade, China should be able to gain greater technological capabilities.

Even if China surpasses the United States as the world’s largest economy at market exchange rates in the next fifteen years (assuming its annual growth averages 4.75% compared with 2% for America) its GDP per person will still be about one-fourth that of America. A country four times as rich as its closest geopolitical foe has, in effect, more spare cash to invest in military forces and R&D. It should have the means to stay ahead of the game, assuming that American leaders can muster the necessary political will and unity.

What is more, China is ageing faster than America. The UN projects that in 2040 the median age in China will be 46.3 years, compared with 41.6 for the United States. As a result, China’s growth is expected to slow down significantly in the 2030s.

In other areas of power, America’s lead will prove insurmountable. It will continue to have the world’s best research universities, most innovative technology firms and most efficient financial markets.

Ironically, the ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP) will be China’s biggest obstacle in its race with America. The party’s existential fear of losing control will impel it to maintain a tight grip on the economy, making it less efficient. Giant but ossified state-owned enterprises will continue to waste resources. The CCP’s arbitrary exercise of power—as exemplified by its sweeping crackdown on China’s most successful tech companies, such as Didi and Alibaba—will stifle the innovation and growth of its tech sector more effectively than America’s sanctions. Most alarmingly, as China descends further into personalistic rule, it will be less able to correct or reverse the questionable decisions made by its top leadership.

Factor in the capabilities of America’s allies, and the balance of power tilts further in America’s favour. Whereas China has no real allies, America is blessed with many. And whereas the United States has no big rivals in its region, China must contend with several powerful adversaries, notably India and Japan, in its immediate neighbourhood. China is far weaker than most people realise.

A China that fails to reach parity with America, let alone surpass it, should not be a cause for celebration in Washington. In fifteen to twenty years, China will have a much bigger economy, more advanced technology and more capable armed forces. It will also remain America’s most formidable rival, and will be able to constrain the exercise of American power globally. The United States will have to devote most of its attention, energy and resources to contesting Chinese power, at the expense of its interests elsewhere.

In short, China should be able to narrow the gap with America in the 2020s, but its growth will probably slow down in the 2030s, and the prospect of China overtaking America will look increasingly dim. If this is the case, the coming decade might be the most volatile because China’s continuing ascent might make its leaders more reckless and Washington less secure.

In fact, a strategic stalemate seems the likeliest outcome. However unsatisfying, this will be a net improvement upon the status quo. Instead of spiralling dangerously out of control, bilateral relations will probably settle at an equilibrium with lower military tensions and far less diplomatic vitriol. America’s security alliance in Asia will remain largely intact, thus preventing China from achieving regional hegemony or absorbing Taiwan. Through arms control and renewed diplomatic engagement reminiscent of the US-Soviet détente, both countries may be able to agree on a set of rules confining their rivalry to a small number of realms unlikely to trigger a full-fledged conflict.

This is not exactly the scenario hoped for by strategists wishing to repeat America’s victory over the Soviet Union in the cold war. Nor is it the “great rejuvenation” President Xi Jinping has in mind. But even without turning China into the world’s most powerful country, the Chinese Communist Party will still be a winner: unlike its defunct Soviet cousin, the CCP will remain solidly in control of a superpower that the Americans fail to vanquish.

________________

Minxin Pei is a professor of government at Claremont McKenna College in California.

item.title: ZULF CONSIDERS WAYS OF APPREHENDING UNIVERSAL TRUTH
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
In Emerson, there is a certain mysteriousness by which self-trust and self examination and a spiritual loftiness within is a source of deep universal truth. This idea of course has a longer history, that there is universal truth to be found within us. There are other more external ways as well, of seeking truth. The scientific method is to seek universal truth by external measurements, by observations and parsimonious coherent theories. It has been an extremely interesting issue for me to understand whether either method is actually accurate and whether their answers actually agree. These are difficult questions, and there are noisy messy answers which are pessimistic, that question whether there is any truth at all, and whether both methods are posturing and meaningless rituals. These are not interesting because they do not yield any actual deep insight.

The approach that I like much more, one that promises some nontrivial answers is to understand the uniformity in our genetic code and genetic co-evolution as the primary concrete basis for the possibility of discovering deep universal truth by turning within. The principle here is that since all our capabilities, of thought and perception are activities of evolutionary adaptations, that which we can agree as universal truth will occur to us independently because our capabilities have genetic regularity.

item.title: AFGHANISTAN ANALYSIS: KISSINGER
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Henry Kissinger on why America failed in Afghanistan

It was not possible to turn the country into a modern democracy, but creative diplomacy and force might have overcome terrorism, says the American statesman

Aug 25th 2021

BY HENRY KISSINGER

Give

This By-invitation commentary is part of a series by global thinkers on the future of American power—examining the forces shaping the country's global standing, from the rise of China to the withdrawal from Afghanistan. Read more here.

THE TALIBAN takeover of Afghanistan focuses the immediate concern on the extrication of tens of thousands of Americans, allies and Afghans stranded all over the country. Their rescue needs to be our urgent priority. The more fundamental concern, however, is how America found itself moved to withdraw in a decision taken without much warning or consultation with allies or the people most directly involved in 20 years of sacrifice. And why the basic challenge in Afghanistan has been conceived and presented to the public as a choice between full control of Afghanistan or complete withdrawal.

An underlying issue has dogged our counterinsurgency efforts from Vietnam to Iraq for over a generation. When the United States risks the lives of its military, stakes its prestige and involves other countries, it must do so on the basis of a combination of strategic and political objectives. Strategic, to make clear the circumstances for which we fight; political, to define the governing framework to sustain the outcome both within the country concerned and internationally.

The United States has torn itself apart in its counterinsurgent efforts because of its inability to define attainable goals and to link them in a way that is sustainable by the American political process. The military objectives have been too absolute and unattainable and the political ones too abstract and elusive. The failure to link them to each other has involved America in conflicts without definable terminal points and caused us internally to dissolve unified purpose in a swamp of domestic controversies.

We entered Afghanistan amid wide public support in response to the al-Qaeda attack on America launched from Taliban-controlled Afghanistan. The initial military campaign prevailed with great effectiveness. The Taliban survived essentially in Pakistani sanctuaries, from which it carried out insurgency in Afghanistan with the assistance of some Pakistani authorities.

But as the Taliban was fleeing the country, we lost strategic focus. We convinced ourselves that ultimately the re-establishment of terrorist bases could only be prevented by transforming Afghanistan into a modern state with democratic institutions and a government that ruled constitutionally. Such an enterprise could have no timetable reconcilable with American political processes. In 2010, in an op-ed in response to a troop surge, I warned against a process so prolonged and obtrusive as to turn even non-jihadist Afghans against the entire effort.

For Afghanistan has never been a modern state. Statehood presupposes a sense of common obligation and centralisation of authority. Afghan soil, rich in many elements, lacks these. Building a modern democratic state in Afghanistan where the government’s writ runs uniformly throughout the country implies a timeframe of many years, indeed decades; this cuts against the geographical and ethnoreligious essence of the country. It was precisely Afghanistan’s fractiousness, inaccessibility and absence of central authority that made it an attractive base for terrorist networks in the first place.
_______________

Read more:

• Our series on American power
• Niall Ferguson on why the end of America’s empire won’t be peaceful
• Francis Fukuyama on the end of American hegemony
_______________

Although a distinct Afghan entity can be dated back to the 18th century, its constituent peoples have always fiercely resisted centralisation. Political and especially military consolidation in Afghanistan has proceeded along ethnic and clan lines, in a basically feudal structure where the decisive power brokers are the organisers of clan defence forces. Typically in latent conflict with each other, these warlords unite in broad coalitions primarily when some outside force—such as the British army that invaded in 1839 and the Soviet armed forces that occupied Afghanistan in 1979—seeks to impose centralisation and coherence.

Both the calamitous British retreat from Kabul in 1842, in which only a single European escaped death or captivity, and the momentous Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan in 1989 were brought about by such temporary mobilisation among the clans. The contemporary argument that the Afghan people are not willing to fight for themselves is not supported by history. They have been ferocious fighters for their clans and for tribal autonomy.

Over time, the war took on the unlimited characteristic of previous counterinsurgency campaigns in which domestic American support progressively weakened with the passage of time. The destruction of Taliban bases was essentially achieved. But nation-building in a war-torn country absorbed substantial military forces. The Taliban could be contained but not eliminated. And the introduction of unfamiliar forms of government weakened political commitment and enhanced already rife corruption.

Afghanistan thereby repeated previous patterns of American domestic controversies. What the counterinsurgency side of the debate defined as progress, the political one treated as disaster. The two groups tended to paralyse each other during successive administrations of both parties. An example is the 2009 decision to couple a surge of troops in Afghanistan with a simultaneous announcement that they would begin to withdraw in 18 months.

What had been neglected was a conceivable alternative combining achievable objectives. Counterinsurgency might have been reduced to the containment, rather than the destruction, of the Taliban. And the politico-diplomatic course might have explored one of the special aspects of the Afghan reality: that the country’s neighbours—even when adversarial with each other and occasionally to us—feel deeply threatened by Afghanistan’s terrorist potential.

Would it have been possible to co-ordinate some common counterinsurgency efforts? To be sure, India, China, Russia and Pakistan often have divergent interests. A creative diplomacy might have distilled common measures for overcoming terrorism in Afghanistan. This strategy is how Britain defended the land approaches to India across the Middle East for a century without permanent bases but permanent readiness to defend its interests, together with ad hoc regional supporters.https://a91857484b1c8c5546fad89cde7f4692.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-38/html/container.html

But this alternative was never explored. Having campaigned against the war, Presidents Donald Trump and Joe Biden undertook peace negotiations with the Taliban to whose extirpation we had committed ourselves, and induced allies to help, 20 years ago. These have now culminated in what amounts to unconditional American withdrawal by the Biden administration.

Describing the evolution does not eliminate the callousness and, above all, the abruptness of the withdrawal decision. America cannot escape being a key component of international order because of its capacities and historic values. It cannot avoid it by withdrawing. How to combat, limit and overcome terrorism enhanced and supported by countries with a self-magnifying and ever more sophisticated technology will remain a global challenge. It must be resisted by national strategic interests together with whatever international structure we are able to create by a commensurate diplomacy.

We must recognise that no dramatic strategic move is available in the immediate future to offset this self-inflicted setback, such as by making new formal commitments in other regions. American rashness would compound disappointment among allies, encourage adversaries, and sow confusion among observers.

The Biden administration is still in its early stages. It should have the opportunity to develop and sustain a comprehensive strategy compatible with domestic and international necessities. Democracies evolve in a conflict of factions. They achieve greatness by their reconciliations.
___________

Henry Kissinger is a former American secretary of state and national security adviser

item.title: THAT IS CORRECT MADAM LAGARDE BILL GATES LAWLESSNESS AND INABILITY TO BE A CIVILISED MAN ENSURES HE IS A THREAT TO GLOBAL FINANCE
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: Global Finance, as one of the leaders of it you are perfectly aware, Madam Lagarde is an essential function to serve the human race and all people. We live in a world where money is the store of value for exchange of goods and services and therefore Finance has the full spectrum of obligations to produce liquid markets for exchanges of essential products and services, ensure the transparency and lack of corruption for financial securities, fair valuation, allocation to all sectors of the world economy as well as the safekeeping and well-being of people's financial health. These broad spectrum functions are crucial to the well being of all people. It is known that financial satisfaction is significantly correlated with life satisfaction of the entire human race at the individual level. We, in Finance, are not directly responsible for particular activities that people around the world to do to make their living but we are responsible for ensuring that our activities are enabling for them, and that we do the best job for all people everywhere to have a better life doing legitimate activities to have fulfilling lives with fewer cares. In other words our fundamental job is service to the human race. We cannot afford to have disruptions of people with predatory intentions at a global scale intrude in our sacred space for we have evolved over some centuries to reach some modicum of civilised organisation. Granted, that our implementation have been imperfect, and financial life for all people everywhere is still filled with uncertainty. But we cannot give up our gains so easily by knowing full well that certain types of criminal and malevolent operators have clear intentions to go against our fundamental goals and principles disrupt our operations. I am of course talking specifically about Bill Gates and others who are criminally malevolent charlatans. These operators have found various sneaky ways to bamboozle people with lies and self-promotion in order to maliciously disrupt our legitimate processes. They cannot be allowed any service in any part of Finance world at all. The interests of the whole human race are irresponsibly hurt when we give even an inch to such a predatory being. He must be repelled in every part of the world of Finance.

item.title: BILL GATES' THOUGHTS ABOUT FINANCE ARE EXTREMELY IRRELEVANT
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Beyond the standard democratic right to an opinion, which everyone has, Bill Gates thoughts about Finance are extremely uninformed and radically stupid. There is proof for this. He literally considered finance parasitic zero sum game in a public conference. No one in Finance respects opinions on a difficult professional discipline by an uncouth malevolent, unrefined hick man without any culture or taste who is a pathological liar.

“I didn’t even want to meet Warren because I thought, ‘Hey this guy buys and sells things, and so he found imperfections in terms of markets, that’s not value added to society, that’s a zero-sum game that is almost parasitic.’ That was my view before I met him … he wasn’t going to tell me about inventing something,”

(Source: CNBC)

Bill Gates ideas here are fundamentally too narrow and ignorant to even contemplate. First of all, he seems to believe that markets exist in a vacuum that is implicit in his assumption. In fact, liquid markets are difficult to create, and Finance creates all liquid markets that exist. We created the Futures Exchanges to solve many problems in commodities, including standardizing contracts. The task of Futures markets, for example crude oil futures is primarily to mitigate business risks of people who pull out, refine, crude oil so that all the people of the world who drive cars based on gasoline can pay cheaper rates for their daily lives. Arbitrageurs have a positive effect in getting prices to be rational, for imperfections force the fair value to be in some bounds in liquid markets. That's just one example. Finance has allowed more things that people need to have fair values and more availability and given people more options to get things they need for fulfilling lives at more reasonable costs. Bill Gates' "inventions" are menial and trivial by comparison.

item.title: THE DELUSIONAL MYTH OF "THOUSAND TIMES SMARTER" OF BILL GATES
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Bill Gates is an illiterate hick without a college degree. I have personally known some of the most talented mathematicians of this age, some of the most talented Finance people as well, and even extremely talented artists. Bill Gates does propaganda about his 160 IQ which is total rubbish. His plebian hick roots show when he does this. People who are talented are talented because they care about what they do, they love what they do, they are reasonably intelligent and educated properly, and they keep focus on problems that are important and then eventually they have clear understanding, some breakthroughs, and coherent new understanding to share with the world. The operative issue is not 'thousand times smarter'. It's not enough to have smartness or IQ or whatever. You need to have interest in the problems, you need to savour the history of the field, appreciate great difficulties, appreciate great efforts and failures. Those things, and not 'thousand times smarter' is what makes talent shine. Bill Gates is a horrible influence on the population because he has a fictional idea of what makes great things possible and projects this myth for bamboozling people and swindling people. Do not believe in 'thousand times smarter' myth. If you don't love something passionately enough to go without food for days working on it, don't do it. Just move to something else. You will never accomplish anything without love for what you do. Do only those things, and you will be great. Do not get obsessed with totally irrelevant IQ scores. It's totally bullshit.

Read the diaries of Kafka, or Musil, of any great genius, of Poincare, and you will see how much sustained devotion goes to blossom their new insights. Genius is a matter of love and continuous effort on something you care about deeply and love. This "thousand times smarter" is superstition; it is a gimmick; it has not substance to it; it is horrible for children, especially children with potential talent because it gives them a false sense that if they are not reaching the pinnacle of understanding without effort then they are failures. No. No. No. Those people do not exist at all. Even Mozart worked very very hard to reach his peak.

item.title: SO MADAM CHRISTINE LAGARDE STILL DOING IMPERIAL AND PATRIARCHAL SYSTEMS HUH?
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
How did American “wokeness” jump from elite schools to everyday life?

And how deep will its influence be?

Sep 4th 2021

WASHINGTON, DC

You could use a single word as a proxy. “Latinx” is a gender-neutral adjective which only 4% of American Hispanics say they prefer. Yet in 2018 the New York Times launched a column dedicated to “Latinx communities”. It has crept into White House press releases and a presidential speech. Google’s diversity reports use the even more inclusive “Latinx+”. A term once championed by esoteric academics has gone mainstream.Listen to this story

The espousal of new vocabulary is one sign of a social mobilisation that is affecting ever more areas of American life. It has penetrated politics and the press. Sometimes it spills out into the streets, in demonstrations calling for the abolition of police departments. It is starting to spread to schools. San Francisco’s education board, which for more than a year was unable to get children into classes, busied itself with stripping the names of Abraham Lincoln and George Washington from its schools, and ridding department names of acronyms such as vapa (Visual and Performing Arts), on the ground that they are “a symptom of white supremacy”.

What links these developments is a loose constellation of ideas that is changing the way that mostly white, educated, left-leaning Americans view the world. This credo still lacks a definitive name: it is variously known as left-liberal identity politics, social-justice activism or, simply, wokeness. But it has a clear common thread: a belief that any disparities between racial groups are evidence of structural racism; that the norms of free speech, individualism and universalism which pretend to be progressive are really camouflage for this discrimination; and that injustice will persist until systems of language and privilege are dismantled.

These notions were incubated for years in the humanities departments of universities (elite ones in particular), without serious challenge. Moral panics about campus culture are hardly new, and the emergence of a new leftism in the early 2010s prompted little concern. Even as students began scouring the words of academics, administrators and fellow students for microaggressions, the oppressive slights embedded in everyday speech, and found them, complacency ruled. When invited speeches from people such as Christine Lagarde, then head of the International Monetary Fund, were cancelled after student activists accused her of complicity in “imperialist and patriarchal systems”, the response was a collective shrug.

The complacency was naive. America harboured a “Vegas campus delusion”, says Greg Lukianoff, president of the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education, an advocacy group. “What happens on campus will not stay on campus.” It has not. The influence of the new social-justice mindset is now being felt in the media, the Democratic Party and, most recently, businesses and schools.

How did this breakout happen? Three things helped prepare the ground: a disaffected student body, an academic theory that was malleable enough to be shaped into a handbook for political activism, and a pliant university administration.

First came a new generation of students keenly aware of unsolved social problems and willing to see old-fashioned precepts of academic freedom (such as open debate) as obstacles to progress. Various events—the financial crisis, the election of Donald Trump, the police killings of unarmed black men, especially that of George Floyd—fed frustration with traditional liberalism’s seeming inability to end long-run inequities. This hastened the adoption of an ideology that offered fresh answers.

In a book entitled “The Coddling of the American Mind”, Mr Lukianoff and a social psychologist, Jonathan Haidt, posit that overprotective parenting in the shadow of the war on terrorism and the great recession led to “safetyism”, a belief that safety, including emotional safety, trumps all other practical and moral concerns. Its bounds grew to require disinviting disfavoured campus speakers (see chart 1), protesting about disagreeable readings and regulating the speech of fellow students.

Many students latched onto a body of theory which yokes obscurantist texts to calls for social action (or “praxis”) that had been developing in the academy for decades. In 1965 Herbert Marcuse, a critical theorist, coined the phrase “repressive tolerance”, the notion that freedom of speech should be withdrawn from the political right in order to bring about progress, since the “cancellation of the liberal creed of free and equal discussion” might be necessary to end oppression. Another influence was Paulo Freire, a Brazilian educator whose “Pedagogy of the Oppressed” (published in English in 1970) advocated a liberatory pedagogy in the spirit of Mao’s Cultural Revolution in which “the oppressed unveil the world of oppression and through the praxis commit themselves to its transformation”.

The Great Awokening

Today the most prominent evangelists for what political scientists such as Zachary Goldberg call the Great Awokening are Ibram X. Kendi and Robin DiAngelo. Both these scholar-activists have written bestselling books that sketch the expansive boundaries of systemic racism. Both minimise the role of intent, but in different ways. In Mr Kendi’s Manichaean worldview actions are either actively narrowing racial gaps, and are therefore anti-racist, or they are not, in which case they are racist. “Capitalism is essentially racist; racism is essentially capitalist,” he concludes.

Ms DiAngelo is concerned with the racism of everyday speech. For her, the intent of the oppressor is immaterial if an oppressed person deems the conduct to be offensive. How “white progressives cause more daily harm [to black people] than, say, white nationalists” is the subject of her latest book, “Nice Racism”. She sees liberal norms like individualism or the aspiration for colour-blind universalism as naive: “Liberalism doesn’t account for power, and the differential in power,” she says.

The embrace of this ideology by students and professors might have remained inconsequential had it not been for the part played by administrative staff. Since 2000, such staff in the University of California system has more than doubled, outpacing the increase in faculty and students. The growth in private universities has been even faster. Between 1975 and 2005 the ranks of administrators grew by 66% in public colleges but by 135% in private ones. As their headcount grew, so did their remit—ferreting out not just overt racism or sexual harassment but implicit bias too. The University of California, Los Angeles, now insists that faculty applying for tenure include a diversity statement.

In 2018 Samuel Abrams, a political scientist at Sarah Lawrence College, published data showing that these administrators are even more left-leaning than the professors: liberals outnumber conservatives by 12 to one. For writing about this, Mr Abrams faced a campaign by outraged students aiming to revoke his tenure. Campaigns by a vocal minority of activists have cast a pall on campus life, he says. “Large numbers of people hate this. They just don’t know what to do,” he laments. “They don’t want the mob coming to them.”

An upheaval in mass communication accelerated the trend. On Twitter, a determined minority can be amplified, and an uneasy centre-left can be cowed. “Weaponisation of social media became part of the game. But what I think nobody foresaw was that these tactics could so easily be imported to the New York Times or Penguin Random House or Google,” says Niall Ferguson, a historian at Stanford’s Hoover Institution. “The invasion…was just a case of the old problem: that liberals defer to progressives. And progressives defer to outright totalitarians.”

Mr Trump’s election added to centrists’ unease, leaving the poles to grow ever more extreme. “Anything but far-left progressivism was lumped in with Trump,” says one (Democratic) prosecutor in San Francisco. In the protest against Mr Trump’s handling of the Mexican border, for instance, the old Democratic line of enhanced border security and a path to citizenship for the long-term undocumented became passé. Progressives proved their sincerity by being in favour of abolishing immigration authorities entirely.

Having grown strong roots, social-justice consciousness has spread most readily to non-academic institutions largely peopled by those who have come through elite universities. As the students who have embraced this messy body of theory leave university, they enter into jobs and positions of influence. The question is whether, outside the ivory tower, the ideology will retain its intolerant and belligerent zeal, or whether it will mellow into a benign urge for society to be a little fairer.

Newspapers are a prime example. The digital revolution has devastated local newspapers and crowned new online-only champions. As newsrooms adapted by aping the upstarts, hacks who had risen through the ranks thanks to shoe-leather reporting were replaced by younger staffers stuffed with new ideas from elite universities. One prominent journalist argued for replacing “neutral objectivity” with “moral clarity”—making unflinching distinctions between right and wrong.

The urge to purge

Changes in newsrooms were also related to efforts to increase demographic diversity, on the assumption that this is the only authentic way to give voice to minorities. But the campus zeal for deplatforming voices deemed offensive and defenestrating those found guilty of violating the ethos has also been imported. (James Bennet, who resigned as editorial-page editor of the New York Times after one such row, now works for The Economist; he was not involved in this article.) Non-journalists on the staff of newspapers, including young engineers, can be even more activist in campaigning against colleagues judged to be producing content at odds with the new vision of social justice.

As with universities, this stridency met little rebuke from the heads of newsrooms. Lee Fang, a left-leaning journalist for “The Intercept”, an online publication specialising in “adversarial journalism”, was accused by a colleague of racism for posting an interview with an African-American supporter of Black Lives Matter who offered a personal criticism of the group. He was made to apologise.

The quiet cultural revolution has also affected the Democratic Party. A decade ago, around 40% of white liberals agreed that “racial discrimination is the main reason why many black people can’t get ahead these days”; today over 70% do (see chart 2). In 2013, according to Gallup, a pollster, 70% of Americans thought black-white race relations were going well; that has dropped to 42%. Among white conservatives and moderates, there has been little movement on such questions.

In the past decade a far greater share of white liberals than African-Americans came to believe that blacks should have “special favours” to get ahead (see chart 3). Ideas for promoting racial equity that once belonged to the Democrats’ left fringe have become mainstream. Cash reparations for African-Americans are supported by 49% of Democrats, for example, and 41% endorse reducing police funding.

Democratic politicians have responded. In 2008 Barack Obama criticised overheated sermons of his pastor, saying “they expressed a profoundly distorted view of this country—a view that sees white racism as endemic, and that elevates what is wrong with America above all that we know is right with America.” The pastor’s view is now ascendant among Democrats.

In 2016 Hillary Clinton started giving speeches on the need to end systemic racism. By 2020 this movement was the defining fault line of the presidential primary. Joe Biden, an avatar for Democratic consensus, won by taking positions far to the left of Mr Obama, including on matters of identity politics. That is why his administration speaks much more social-justice patois than Mr Obama’s ever did. And why it embraces reparations-adjacent policies like the creation of a $4bn fund to pay off the debts of only non-white farmers, and a proposal that 40% of benefits from climate-change investment go to previously disadvantaged communities.

Wokers of the world, unite!

This new political prominence makes the question of what happens to the ideology of social activism as it spreads beyond the ivory tower all the more important. Does it retain its purity and potency? Or does it become diluted?

The corporate world will be a big test. Businesses, particularly those in the knowledge economy, have been grappling with the challenge of how to respond to social-justice consciousness as young employees agitate for change and woke consumers threaten boycotts.

An increasingly common argument is that there is no trade-off between greater diversity and profits. “I’d like to get to a place where we thought that diverse representation was just as important as profitability, because we believed it was linked to so many things that were going to come back and drive value,” says Julie Coffman, the chief diversity officer of Bain & Company, a management consultancy. Others make an explicit business case. McKinsey, another consultancy, has released a stream of reports arguing that firms with greater ethnic and gender diversity have a greater chance of financial outperformance.

Since Floyd’s murder, American businesses have issued a dizzying number of equity-related missives and quotas for hiring and procurement. Facebook, a social-media giant, has promised to hire 30% more black people in leadership positions and has set a goal that “50% of our workforce be from underrepresented communities by the end of 2023”. Target, a retailer, has pledged to spend more than $2bn with black-owned businesses by the end of 2025. Walmart, another retail titan, has set up a Centre for Racial Equity and says it will give it $100m to “address the drivers of systemic racism”.

Importing the language of equity without university-style blow-ups can be difficult. “What you’re seeing is Gen Z or young millennials basically engaging in this collective war against the boomers and the Gen Xers who actually run the organisations,” says Antonio García Martínez, whom Apple fired in May after 2,000 employees circulated a petition questioning his hiring, citing passages they found to be misogynistic in an autobiography published five years ago. When Brian Armstrong, the boss of Coinbase, announced that workplace activism was to be discouraged, he was inundated with private messages of admiration from ceos who felt that they could not do the same—and public criticism.

“Corporate wokeism I believe is the product of self-interest intermingled with the appearance of pursuing social justice,” says Vivek Ramaswamy, a former biotechnology executive and author of “Woke, Inc.”. He argues that Big Tech pursues corporate wokeism because appearing to embrace social justice suits such firms’ commercial interests—both in terms of recruitment and appeal to their customers. It performs allegiance to identity politics while simultaneously rejecting the left’s critique of capitalism. “A lot of Big Tech has agreed to bend to the progressive left,” he says, but “they effectively expect that the new left look the other way when it comes to leaving their monopoly power.”

Such hypocrisy is increasingly prevalent. The founder of Salesforce, a tech behemoth based in San Francisco, is known for championing social-justice causes like a surtax to fund homelessness services in the city. Yet the firm itself paid no federal taxes on $2.6bn in profits in 2020.

Wokeness’s next frontier, with the greatest potential to make a mark on the future, will be the classroom. In California’s recently approved ethnic-studies curriculum, which may become a high-school graduation requirement, one lesson plan aims to help students “dispel the model-minority myth” (the idea that to dwell on Asian-American success is wrong). Roughly one-sixth of the state’s proposed new maths instruction framework is devoted to social justice. It approvingly quotes from studies suggesting that word problems about boys and girls knitting scarves be accompanied by a debate about gender norms. Last month the governor of Oregon signed a bill eliminating high-school graduation requirements of proficiency in reading, writing and maths until 2024—justified as necessary to promote equity for non-white students.

Woker or weaker?

Such proposals hint at the difficulties of translating some of the theories embraced by the new left into policy. Because disparities are theorised to be the result of largely implicit discrimination, systems must be dismantled. This leads to odd conclusions: that racial test-score gaps in maths can be ameliorated by dialectic; and that not testing for the ability to read is a worthy substitute for teaching it. Material conditions that the old left cared about, such as persistent segregation in poor districts and schools, get little attention.

There are some signs of a backlash. Three members of San Francisco’s board of education, including its president, are under threat of a recall election. So is the city’s ultra-progressive district attorney. However, the underlying engine—the questionable ideas of some academics, and the generational change they are rendering—is not shutting off. America has not yet reached peak woke. ■

This article appeared in the Briefing section of the print edition under the headline "Out of the academy"

Anyway, so I would defocus my eyes and in my right eye i could see something transparent that looked like a mathematical graph with circular stops, a bit like how London Underground stops are on the maps. I saw it a few times, and decided that this was some secret special map I was born with, obviously of stars and galaxies. Stars and galaxies I had already traveled. I, Zulfikar Moinuddin Ahmed, was then here in a next leg, and the map showed me other places I had been to before. It occurred a few times and then I forgot about it. Many decades later, in New York, I was much more sure that this was true, and I was an Archangel Soul who was having an Earth life, having had one more as Englishman between 1180-1300 sometime. His life is so shallow and fake compared to mine. Obviously he is a secondary minor character in my eternal life. Quite annoying these days, because I was not actually prepared several years ago of a murder plot by anyone wealthy in America.

Even as a child Godhood did not appeal to me. I was born in a Muslim family, and I was already aware that five times of prayers ended with people asking God for all manner of things. My reasoning would have been quite simple, that it is dreadfully complicated keeping track of everyone's prayers five times a day. item.title: RICHARD HOLMES ON QUEEN MAB
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Queen Mab is subversive in intent, vigorously polemic in attack, and revolutionary in content and implication. Its main targets are established religion, political tyranny, destructive forces of war and commerce, perversion of love by marriage institution and prostitution. Secondary themes are temperance, republican austerity, righteous moral independence of judgment. (Richard Holmes, Shelley The Pursuit p. 201)

Not being as articulate and talented in poetry as Shelley, I am not able to consolidate my own views yet on some of these. I am a great Shelley devotee but do not agree with his 1813 views on many issues. For example, the idea that the institution of marriage is a perversion of pure love is a thoroughly wrong view to me. I do have strong convictions about the centrality of love in relations between men and women but do not consider the institution of marriage to be an oppressive end except when there is no actual love that is worth preserving. Here I think Shelley is rather immature and his string of loves were not exemplary for their successes. The radical subversion of institution of marriage is not at all the correct answer to the problems of love but would in the end produce much greater problems. On this I will have much more to say in the future because I am interested in this topic. Political tyranny is as horrible today as it was during Shelley's time, but I have gone through the issues of challenge to established religions already and have decided that they are not worth fighting for they have the tendency to absorb all things meant to upset them and survive. I have alternative views about how to mitigate the destructive forces of war and commerce. Richard Holmes' summary is valuable to me. I am willing to be far more radical than Shelley if necessary actually, but I no longer find the instinctive rush to total subversion as attractive as in my youth. There are better processes.

What was possible for Shelley that is less possible for me is to actually consider total revolution as a fully positive thing and being free to examine it. I am Finance, and my phase of this type led to seeking abolition of all Nation States for a Great Republic of Humanity with Natural Rights secured for the entire Human Race. I cannot deny strong influence of Shelley, especially a boldness in seeking a loftier idea than what society of the world demands by exit. I am returning to the ordinary world of actual business processes but I don't see things in terms of total subversion versus more compromised convictions. Rather, I think the issue is precisely to adapt understanding to Human Nature. This is not possible by total flights into the 'artistic metaphysics' which is what Nietzsche did in The Birth of Tragedy. I'll tell you the sort of picture that I have instead. I like the idea that we live in two worlds, one is complete autonomy in a totally subjective world, an artistic world, and that is more important than the 'real world' when we are with our lovers. But it is a very difficult task to begin to seek a political revolution from that world by its pure ideals for the actual human race. And that is what Shelley was interested in. He did not care about realistic transformations but in purity of that inner world. The way I see it is that the ability to step in and out of the romantic inner world is the mark of maturity of a human being, especially without losing integrity of one's own inner world or not understanding that the entire world does not belong in that world; it's your world, your world with your beloved. The rest of the world, would bring their muddy bootprints and ruin it. It is also not what the rest of the world can tolerate either; for them it would be intolerable tyranny. Shelley did not worry about this. This is why he was a great poetic genius and not Mahatma Gandhi or Martin Luther King Jr. He was not actually any good as a great leader of men.

And I am positing that the enormously difficult and delicate balance of Romantic Self and Sociopolitical Self is the essential process of Human Race evolution. Now we can call this something other than Romantic Self what I am trying to express, but we ought to honour the Romantic poets for truly discovering this for us, and call it Romantic Self. item.title: MY ABANDONED GLOBAL REPUBLIC IDEA
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded: The idea is to produce a Global Natural Rights Security organisation and demote Nations as relative autonomous states. So Natural Right Security for everyone in the world would be an International organisation's duty (including policing locally). Then orthogonal to this local governance functions would not involve Natural Rights breaches at all. Instead it would be local issues, what bridges and tunnels to build, how to deal with local economy, etc. Local means National roughly. Then political system would be decomposed into fundamental Natural Rights security and orthogonal issues of governance. This would eliminate wars because you're not actually allowed to violate anyone's Natural Rights, so you pool together some Defense things as a vestige of old ways under Natural Rights security emergency. This would reduce expenses for everyone and guarantee that Natural Rights security is higher quality. Then local sovereignty cannot touch Natural Rights security issues but can have autonomy on other things like zoning laws just as things work now. Now there can still be immigration controls etc. That's not a serious problem. The problem is that the current system is deficient in universal Natural Rights security.

That sort of approach will lead to dystopian reaction like the Cultural Revolution in China. Instead things work better if we have a pulse of the well-being of the entire human race and then slowly titrate big Global Natural Rights ideas very slowly with measurements that gauge slowly how the well-being is affected on small steps. The big ideas and concepts are good goal orientation for the process. You have to always keep in mind that human nature is still mysterious, and we should be careful not to use blunt weapons and clobber a complex sophisticated civilisation. Gentle pushes with lots of measurements will tell us whether things have vast improvement, no improvement, or degradation. There is no point making large changes that will just end up having devastation on lives of billions.

item.title: THE VALUE OF BILL GATES TO AMERICA IS MUCH LESS THAN ZERO

American Government is obligated to value me and secure my Natural Rights, which forces their hand to kill Bill Gates since he has done massive irreparable harm to me already and poses a threat to my life. He plotted my murder and caused enormous unjustified harm to me already. He is a malevolent evil criminal and both US Government and UN Security Council have no choice but to kill him if they want to stay consistent with US Declaration Preamble and UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights. But there is a separate question, of incidental interest, which is whether there are good reasons to value myself or Bill Gates higher. Let us assume that Bill Gates and I were not in a situation where these organisations were not forced to kill Bill Gates. Then let us ask what value does Bill Gates have versus what value do I have for America. All my work and ideas are forward looking. I have given the world concrete empirical results on Universal Human Nature such as (a) existence of Universal Human Moral Nature, (b) rough ethnicity independence of Universal Human Moral Nature, (c) concrete empirical vindication of Aristotle's Virtue Theory by Life Satisfaction relation to Moral Values, and other results that establish justification for study of Quantitative Human Nature. These are genuine advances over the great moral theorists of West such as Adam Smith and Immanuel Kant, Georg Friedrich Hegel, and others. None of them suspected Universal Human Moral Nature at all. I am quite familiar with the foundations of America and International Law from the end of the Great War via United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights and UN Security Council to maintain global peace and security. I am working on Global Life Satisfaction now and attempting to secure some allocation from European Central Bank and Bank of New York Mellon to produce some work in San Francisco, the Spiritual Home of United Nations. I am an urban American with stellar academic background from Princeton University, well read and have wide perspective about positive future for my beloved people the Human Race. I have not spent my life as a wealthy dilettante. I also have extremely good Virtues including exceptional Honesty. I do not have great financial success but I am not a predatory man. I believe in progress in Civilisation. I am influenced by Percy Bysshe Shelley, by Romatic idealism, and Thomas Stearns Eliot, and my values, despite my background are Western, closer to European than American, and further from Islamic values. I feel quite at home in San Francisco. My political opinions are overall center-left on public matters these days.

The problem with Bill Gates is that he is simply not educated in matters of Civilisation at all. He does not understand John Locke and Thomas Jefferson and the republican principles that founded America at all. He does not even understand that this is a multi-ethnic classical liberal democratic republic but had acquired many illicit powers such as US War power that he employed against myself, an American, without suspecting that this might be a grave crime. He does not respect United States Law and constantly lies. He has no concept of ethics at all, considering himself so big that he has been routinely murdering people for more than forty years. There is nothing that he can offer the world that has any positive value at all because his convictions are about white racial domination of Earth and not principles that are accepted by all of human race today. These characteristics make his value to the United States less than zero. I am far more valuable than him both in my achievements to date -- as both Steven Weinberg and Ed Witten acknowledge that Four-Sphere Theory for macroscopic physics theory is correct -- and my plans which are heartfelt for the benefit of my beloved people the human race. There is very little question at least in my mind that I am infinitely more valuable for America and the world than Bill Gates because his vision for the future is white tribal domination of Earth, and mine is a harmonious Human Race Civilisation with higher well-being for all people. This difference in visions for future of human race is sufficient to make his value to America less than mine.

item.title: BILL GATES IS AN ENEMY OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE THE MOMENT HE USURPS ANY US GOVERNMENT POWER

item.content:encoded: United States is quite young as a country, so some of these issues are simply not clear enough to people. In order to understand this, it is easiest to consider Monarchic power. Suppose you have a Kingdom with Divine King named Hans Castorp. He's the Divine King who is the legitimate heir to the throne. item.title: MORE THOUGHTS ABOUT ROMANTIC REVOLUTION IN EUROPE
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
The Romantic Revolution in Literature 1790-1820 can be seen as the locus of expression of the lofty subjective ambitions that were long suppressed that could find public expression as a celebration of the French Revolution. I like to see it in this way because the political aspect is just a pretext here. The success of the French Revolution in a sense opened the door for public expression of individual subjective realities that were suppressed for a long time and the freedom the Romantic Poets used to express their genius in exhibiting the sublime and the lofty that was hidden within subjective consciousness. At the same time the understanding of what the Romantic Poets were bringing to the public sphere is still mysterious two centuries later. I will posit that they were bringing out the necessity and universality of the Romantic Self in human affairs, and this is an insight that has not been fully grasped even today in 2021. We live today in a Primitive Mercantile Age of Man globally, and there is automatically a denigration of the individual who is reduced to labour and whose value is constrained in various ways. I am seeking now $500 mn allocation from ECB and Christine Lagarde and will produce some organisations for Global Life Satisfaction but I see right through these enslavers and exploiters like Bill Gates whose ambitions demand that all other people be denigrated and reduced to service to his avarice. This is not Marxism. I do not believe there is a class conflict here. I would never consider Bill Gates the most base and vile and crass human being ever born on earth to represent any class at all. He is just a vile ignorant criminal, a trickster, an ignorant charlatan. This is much more subtle than any Marxist theoretical left-wing view here.

What is truly important is that in our professional and public lives, we must consider a different aspect of our selves that is important, and Romantic Self is as necessary as ever regardless. And this balancing between the Romantic Self and the Public Self is one of the crucial aspects that must be clear for a better future for my Beloved People the Human Race.

item.title: ROMANTICISM IN THE MAKING OF THE MODERN MIND?
item.dc:creator: zulfikar.ahmed@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
Jonathan Bate argues that Romanticism had major influence on the Modern Mind, following Isaiah Berlin who considered the Romantic movement to have been the most influence on all that came afterward. These are reasonable, but I take a different view, one that comes from Stanley Corngold's essays on Fate of the Self, which is that there is a gigantic ironic distance from the Romantic Self today, and always had been. My paradigm of the greatest Romantic poet is Percy Bysshe Shelley, not Keats or Wordsworth. What is clear is that there is an element of Romantic Self that is extremely distant from the Modern Self. Perhaps hidden away in academic elements it is possible to think otherwise, but the serious issues of the current moment is obviously an obsession with career and family, and these are the dominant concerns of most people around the world. The most important concern of the Modern Mind is to produce financial security in an insecure world.

At stake in the mystery of understanding Romantic Poets, the universal truths that they had discovered is the difference between Subjective Reality of Individuals and the Public Social Reality. The latter is of course the subject of a great deal of constant discussion, are incessantly the topic of professional resumes, public presentations, and so on. The Subjective Reality is not actually considered substantial in public discourse, but it is crucial and much more important in many ways to the lives that we live, and of profound importance for the well-being of the Human Race. It is this aspect that is still in a completely primitive state across the world.

Soundgarden's "The Day I Tried To Live" just touches the tip of the iceberg; and this is not a local Western concern at all and affects the entire globe.

From my point of view, the entire current Age is a Primitive Mercantile Age for the entire world. Now Romantic Age was at the aftermath of the French Revolution and in Europe, the Romantic Age represents a rupture moment, a transition that had opened up the public understanding of Autonomy of the Subjective Self, which was repressed before, but in fact the long term transition did not produce a convergence that is satisfactory. What happened in 1850s was British Empire across the globe, then what happened in early 1900s was First World War and 1940s the Second World War, then the Cold War ideological struggles across the globe. Overall it is a Primitive Mercantile Age at the moment still. So the potential of the Romantic Self as a universal element of Human Nature is still a matter for the future.
